metadata.titleEn: Dataset of ice core-snow black carbon content on the Tibetan Plateau (1950-2006)
metadata.description:
The data set of ice core-snow black carbon content on the Tibetan plateau (1950-2006) contains five (5) tables: 1 Xu et al. 2006 AG, 2 Xu et al. 2009 PNAS_Conc., 3 Xu et al. 2009 PNAS_flux, 4 Xu et al. 2012 ERL, 5 Wang et al. 2015 ACP.
The data collection sites include the Meikuang glacier, Dongkemadi, Qiangyong, Kangwure, Naimona’nyi, Muztagata, Rongbuk, Tanggula Mountain, Ningjin Gangsang, Zuoqipu, and Glacier No. 1 at the headwaters of the Ürüqi River. The latitudes and longitudes of the collection locations, elevations and other information are marked in the data.
The main indicators of the data are location, time, organic carbon (OC), elemental carbon (EC), black carbon (BC) content and flux.
Location: latitude and longitude
Time: year or date
OC: organic carbon
EC: elemental carbon
BC: Black carbon
Conc.: content, unit: ng g-1
Flux: flux, unit: mg m-2a-1
The data come from the following subjects.
1.	National Program on Key Basic Research Project (973 Program)：Temporal and Spatial Characteristics and Remote Sensing Modeling of Global Change Sensitive Factors; Person in charge: Baiqing Xu; Unit: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology.
2.	National Key Basic Research Program: The Response of Formation and Evolution on the Tibetan Plateau to Global Changes and Adaptation Strategy; Person in charge: Tandong Yao; Unit: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Supported by the Ministry of Science and Technology.
3.	The General Program of National Natural Science Foundation of China: High-resolution Carbon Black Recording in Snow Ice of the Tibetan Plateau; Person in charge: Baiqing Xu; Unit: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC).
4.	The General Program of the National Natural Science Foundation of China: Extraction of Climate and Environment Information from Ice Core Encapsulated Gas on the Tibetan Plateau; Person in charge: Baiqing Xu; Unit: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC).
5.	National Natural Science Foundation of China for Distinguished Young Scholars: Snow and Ice-Atmospheric Chemistry and Environmental Changes on the Tibetan Plateau; Person in charge: Baiqing Xu; Unit: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC).
6.	National Natural Science Foundation of China for Distinguished Young Scholars: Study on the Changes of Aerosol Emissions and Combustion in Human Activities in South Asia in the Past 100 Years; Person in charge: Mo Wang; Unit: Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC).
Observation methods: two-step heating method, thermal/optical carbon analysis method, and single-particle black carbon aerosol photometer.

background: Anthropogenic aerosols may play an important role in climatic change through the worldwide acceleration of glacier melting. As the dominant fractions of fine atmospheric aerosols, carbonaceous particles and sulfate have received special attention due to their strong light-absorbing and scattering properties, respectively. In cold regions, submicron black EC either trapped in snow and ice crystals or deposited directly on the surface may reduce the surface albedo and warm snow and ice by absorbing solar radiation. Recent decades have witnessed exceptional economic development and population increases in Asia, resulting in serious air pollution accompanying higher energy demands. Air pollutants and aerosol particulates from biomass burning and industrial emissions appear to be the major cause of the Asian Brown Cloud. Apart from Greenland and Antarctica, the high-elevation Tibetan Plateau is one of the largest snow and ice areas of the world. Previous studies suggest that the regional lower atmospheric warming trend associated with the thick haze has contributed to the melting of Tibetan glaciers, threatening the water supply of 60% of the world's population that live in this region.
research objective: This study presents a high-resolution ice core record of anthropogenic aerosol concentrations from the southeastern Tibetan Plateau, close to the northern limit of the Asian Brown Cloud.
challenges: Despite its importance, few studies have included measurements of carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in Tibetan snow. Consequently, few data exist regarding the deposition of the Asian Brown Cloud on snow and ice, which has precluded an accurate evaluation of the impact of anthropogenic aerosols on Himalayan glacier retreat and radiative forcing.
methods: During the summer of 2006, a 29 m ice core was retrieved at an elevation of 5500 m above sea level (asl) on the PLZ4 glacier using an electromechanical drill. The ice samples for measurement of carbonaceous aerosols were prepared at a temperature of -20°C in a class 100 clean room. The outer approximately 1.0 cm portion of each section was pared away with a precleaned scalpel. EC and WIOC analysis was achieved using a Desert Research Institute (DRI) Model 2001 Thermal/Optical Carbon Analyzer (Atmoslytic Inc., Calabasas, California). The second column of ice core was cut at 10 cm intervals into 289 sections and allowed to melt at room temperature. Oxygen isotope ratios were determined via the classical headspace equilibration technique using a MAT-253 isotope mass spectrometer.
findings: Annual and seasonal concentrations of EC, WIOC, and inorganic ions in the ice core increased from 1998 to 2005. For carbonaceous matter, the increase was more moderate than for inorganic ions (a factor of 3 for EC and 2.2 for WIOC). Concentrations of nss-SO4 2/C0 are mainly due to fossil fuel emissions, and ionic compositions dominated by nss-SO4 2/C0,N H4 +, and NO3 /C0(over 43% of the total inorganic ion concentration) in the PLZ4 ice core all implicate combustion sources. The main source of EC is predominantly from combustion emissions, although no major pollution sources exist adjacent to the remote location of the high-elevation drill site (5500 m asl). Atmospheric pollutants emitted in South Asia can be transported year-round to the southeastern Tibetan Plateau glacier region under monsoon conditions and by the westerlies.

Verification.Question: Do the data collection methods include thermal/optical carbon analysis for measuring organic and elemental carbon?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection method is more commonly used for measuring black carbon in ice cores: the two-step heating method, thermal/optical carbon analysis, or single-particle soot photometer?
Are datasets about black carbon concentrations in the Tibetan Plateau more frequently generated through direct ice core drilling, atmospheric sampling, or remote sensing techniques?

Is the challenge in studying carbonaceous aerosols in the Tibetan Plateau more related to the lack of measurement data, difficulties in accessing glacier sites, or understanding the transport mechanisms of pollutants?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used to measure black carbon concentrations in glacier ice cores?
Concept Completion.Answer: Two-step heating method, thermal/optical carbon analysis, single-particle black carbon aerosol photometry

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the ice core samples for black carbon studies collected on the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: Coal Mine Glacier, Dongkemadi, Qiangyong, Kangwure, Nam Co, Muztagh Ata, Rongbuk, Tanggula Mountains, Ninjingkangsang, Zuoqiup, Tianshan Urumqi Glacier No.1

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure black carbon concentrations in ice cores from high-elevation regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to measure black carbon concentrations in ice cores involves the use of a Desert Research Institute (DRI) Model 2001 Thermal/Optical Carbon Analyzer. Ice samples for measurement of carbonaceous aerosols are prepared in a class 100 clean room, and the outer portion of each ice section is pared away before analysis.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a specific challenge faced when collecting data on anthropogenic aerosol concentrations in snow and ice from remote glacial regions?
Example.Answer: A specific challenge when collecting data on anthropogenic aerosol concentrations in snow and ice from remote glacial regions is the scarcity of studies measuring carbonaceous aerosol concentrations, which limits the data available for evaluating the impact of anthropogenic aerosols on glacier retreat and radiative forcing.

Example.Question: Provide an example of a high-resolution dataset used to evaluate the impact of anthropogenic aerosols on the Tibetan Plateau glaciers.
Example.Answer: An example of a high-resolution dataset used to evaluate the impact of anthropogenic aerosols on the Tibetan Plateau glaciers includes measurements of annual and seasonal concentrations of elemental carbon (EC), water-insoluble organic carbon (WIOC), and inorganic ions from an ice core retrieved from the southeastern Tibetan Plateau, which showed increased concentrations from 1998 to 2005.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main indicators measured in a dataset related to ice core analysis in the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: location, time, organic carbon, elemental carbon, black carbon content, black carbon flux

Feature Specification.Question: What are the typical data collection methods used to analyze carbonaceous aerosols in ice cores from high-elevation regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: two-step heating method, thermal/optical carbon analysis, single-particle black carbon aerosol photometer

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are associated with measuring carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in snow and ice on the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: limited number of studies, limited data on carbonaceous aerosol concentrations, deposition of the Asian Brown Cloud on snow and ice

Definition.Question: What is the 'two-step heating method' in the context of collecting carbon data from ice cores?
Definition.Answer: The 'two-step heating method' is a data collection technique used for measuring carbon content, specifically organic carbon (OC) and elemental carbon (EC), in ice and snow samples. It involves heating the sample in two distinct phases to separate and quantify different types of carbonaceous materials, allowing researchers to analyze their concentration and flux within the ice cores.

Definition.Question: What does 'single particle soot photometer' mean in the context of aerosol measurement?
Definition.Answer: The 'single particle soot photometer' is an instrument used to measure black carbon aerosols by detecting individual soot particles. It uses laser-induced incandescence to determine the size and concentration of black carbon particles in atmospheric samples, providing detailed insights into their contribution to air pollution and climate change.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of different thermal/optical carbon analysis methods impact the interpretation of black carbon concentration trends in ice core data?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of different thermal/optical carbon analysis methods, such as those employed in the described data collection methods, could affect the interpretation of black carbon concentration trends by influencing the accuracy and sensitivity of the measurement of elemental carbon and organic carbon in ice cores.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes that lead to the challenges in measuring carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in Tibetan snow?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Despite its importance, few studies have included measurements of carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in Tibetan snow, leading to a lack of data regarding the deposition of the Asian Brown Cloud on snow and ice. This scarcity of data precludes an accurate evaluation of the impact of anthropogenic aerosols on Himalayan glacier retreat and radiative forcing.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might the concentration of carbonaceous matter in ice cores increase more moderately compared to inorganic ions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The annual and seasonal concentrations of EC, WIOC, and inorganic ions in the ice core increased from 1998 to 2005. For carbonaceous matter, the increase was more moderate than for inorganic ions, which might be due to differences in the sources and transportation processes of these particles.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the transportation of atmospheric pollutants to the southeastern Tibetan Plateau glacier region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Atmospheric pollutants emitted in South Asia can be transported year-round to the southeastern Tibetan Plateau glacier region under monsoon conditions and by the westerlies, which contribute to the presence of pollutants at high-elevation sites despite the absence of major local pollution sources.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences on the accuracy of black carbon, organic carbon, and elemental carbon measurements when utilizing the two-step heating method compared to single-step methods in ice core analysis?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The accuracy of measurements may improve with the two-step heating method, as it allows for more precise differentiation and analysis of carbon content. This method can provide a more detailed understanding of the composition and sources of carbonaceous aerosols trapped in ice cores, potentially leading to more accurate assessments of their impact on glacial melting and climate change.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting data on black carbon and elemental carbon concentrations in the Tibetan Plateau's ice cores?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include understanding the impact of anthropogenic aerosols on climatic change, particularly related to glacier melting, and evaluating the deposition of the Asian Brown Cloud on snow and ice. This data is crucial for assessing the radiative forcing and the role of carbonaceous aerosols in the retreat of Himalayan glaciers.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to utilize specific data collection methods like the two-step heating method and thermal/optical carbon analysis for measuring carbon concentrations in high-altitude ice cores?
Goal Orientation.Answer: These methods are important because they provide accurate measurements of organic and elemental carbon concentrations in ice cores, which are critical for assessing the deposition and impact of anthropogenic aerosols in the region. The precision of these methods is necessary to understand the sources and effects of carbonaceous particles in the Tibetan Plateau's sensitive environment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers determine the specific locations for ice core drilling on glaciers in the Tibetan Plateau, and what instrumental methods are used to record the geographical data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers choose specific locations for ice core drilling on glaciers based on factors such as elevation, accessibility, and the potential for climatic and environmental insights. Instrumental methods used to record geographical data include marking the latitude, longitude, and elevation of the drilling sites, ensuring accurate documentation of the collection point.

Enablement.Question: What techniques and methods enable the accurate measurement of carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in ice cores from high-altitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a Desert Research Institute (DRI) Model 2001 Thermal/Optical Carbon Analyzer, combined with precise preparation of ice samples in a clean room environment, enables accurate measurement of carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in ice cores from high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methodologies facilitate the understanding of black carbon's impact on glacial melting in the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The application of two-step heating and thermal/optical carbon analysis methods allows for detailed measurement of organic carbon, elemental carbon, and black carbon concentrations, which are crucial for understanding their impact on glacial melting in the Tibetan Plateau.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a lack of comprehensive datasets measuring carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in Tibetan snow?
Expectation.Answer: Few studies have included measurements of carbonaceous aerosol concentrations in Tibetan snow, which limits data on the deposition of the Asian Brown Cloud on snow and ice, impacting the evaluation of anthropogenic aerosols on glacier retreat.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the difficulty in collecting high-resolution ice core records of anthropogenic aerosol concentrations on the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The high-elevation and remote location of the Tibetan Plateau, combined with the need for specialized equipment like an electromechanical drill and controlled environments for sample preparation, can make it challenging to retrieve and analyze ice core records.

Expectation.Question: Why might the anticipated increase in carbonaceous matter concentrations in ice cores be more moderate compared to inorganic ions?
Expectation.Answer: While annual and seasonal concentrations of EC, WIOC, and inorganic ions have increased, the more moderate increase in carbonaceous matter compared to inorganic ions may be influenced by the predominant contribution of combustion emissions and the transport of atmospheric pollutants under specific climatic conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How might researchers evaluate the effectiveness and accuracy of different data collection methods used for assessing black carbon concentrations in glacier ice and snow?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers might evaluate the effectiveness and accuracy of data collection methods like the two-step heating method, thermal/optical carbon analysis, and single-particle black carbon aerosol photometry by comparing results across different studies, assessing consistency in measurements, and validating findings against known standards or alternative methods.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how the two-step heating method and thermal/optical carbon analysis contribute to the accuracy of black carbon measurements in ice cores.
Assertion.Answer: The two-step heating method and thermal/optical carbon analysis are critical for accurately measuring black carbon in ice cores because they allow for the differentiation between organic carbon (OC) and elemental carbon (EC), which are essential components in assessing black carbon content. These methods provide a precise way to quantify carbonaceous aerosols by heating the sample in a controlled environment, enabling researchers to capture the thermal properties and optical characteristics of the carbon particles.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe potential challenges faced in the collection of ice core samples from high-altitude glaciers and how these challenges might affect data accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting ice core samples from high-altitude glaciers include difficult access due to remote and rugged terrain, extreme weather conditions, and maintaining sample integrity during retrieval and transport. These factors can affect data accuracy by potentially compromising sample purity or causing loss of volatile compounds, leading to discrepancies in measured concentrations of carbonaceous aerosols.

Request/Directive.Question: What data collection methods are employed to measure black carbon content in ice core samples, and how do they ensure precision and reliability in the data?
Request/Directive.Answer: The primary data collection methods for measuring black carbon content in ice core samples include the two-step heating method, thermal/optical carbon analysis, and single-particle black carbon aerosol photometry. These methods ensure precision and reliability by accurately distinguishing between different forms of carbon particles and minimizing contamination or alteration of samples during analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential sources of datasets that could be integrated to enhance the understanding of carbonaceous aerosol deposition in Tibetan Plateau glaciers.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources of datasets that could be integrated include regional atmospheric monitoring data, satellite remote sensing data on aerosol distribution, historical climate records, and datasets from related studies on air pollution and aerosol composition in Asia. These sources can provide complementary information on atmospheric conditions and emission sources, enhancing the understanding of carbonaceous aerosol deposition dynamics.
